quote: So, for personal tasks, I really try to limit my use of AI, because out of ecological conviction I really want to restrict it to professional-level tasks.
I'm aware and informed that using generative AI, for example to do a search, consumes a lot more energy, water and electricity than doing a search on Google.

I've heard a lot of people say they talk with ChatGPT to organize their vacations, like having a detailed itinerary when you go somewhere. For example, I know it could save me time, but again, for the reasons I mentioned, I prefer not to do it.
since I haven't downloaded ChatGPT or another AI app on my phone, my use is really limited to when I'm at home in front of my computer.
I haven't had a situation where I needed it to an excessive degree. I always manage to do things as before and find an alternative solution to meet my needs.

I'm really more interested in a personal assistant in a professional context. As I said, not for personal use, but for professional use. Ideally for me it would even be to have several assistants, each with a specific specialty, who could help me in my freelance activity on a daily basis.
an assistant who would handle all the administrative side, the paperwork, sending invoices
an assistant who would help me with content strategy, helping me write content, notably on LinkedIn
an assistant who would have more of a sales hat and would help me with outreach and prospecting potential clients.
The content strategy assistant would help me with everything related to content creation, so mainly for me on LinkedIn, to help me write quality posts without it taking too much of my time.

That assistant would be more in a context where I have a lot of invoices to send. It would really help me with sending invoices, follow-ups if invoices aren't paid on time, and all the administrative part related to services, with all the tasks to manage.

So maybe it could help me create email sequences more easily, instead of managing all that manually today. There would certainly be things that could be automated without having to, for example, subscribe to a tool for all that CRM email-sending part.
I don't use any today, so in any case on the email automation part, I don't have tools that allow me to do that. Hence the interest maybe of being helped by AI on that part.

the fact that the questions are written, ultimately, I find that less disruptive than the tool tested just before where it's really a conversation. I'm more comfortable with the fact that here, the questions and follow-ups are done in writing.

I'm a bit more skeptical when the AI takes the form of voice notes versus the written side. I think we shouldn't forget that we're addressing a machine, and for those reasons, I find it more fluid for me to interact this way.

the fact that exchanges go through writing—sure, it's less human—but in any case, it doesn't make the person in front think they're interacting with a real human. It really puts back the place it actually has, I find.
